facts.text: Ajmer Singh was tried for the murder of Bagher Singh and acquitted by the Sessions Judge of Ferozepore by judgment dated 13th May 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MAHAJAN J.-Ajmer Singh, a young man of about 22 years of age was tried for the murder of Bagher Singh, his first cousin, and was acquitted by the Sessions Judge of Ferozepore by his judgment dated 13th May, 1950.

facts.text: On appeal by the State Government, the High Court set aside the acquittal and convicted Ajmer Singh under section 304 IPC and sentenced to ten years rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the State Government, the order of acquittal was set aside by the High Court and the appellant was convicted under section 304, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced to ten years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave against the High Court decision in Criminal Appeal No. 361 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE.JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No . 67 of 1952. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 14th September, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Punjab at Simla Bhandari and Soni JJ. in Criminal Appeal No. 361 of 1950

facts.text: Nikka Singh had three sons: Bhagwan Singh, Lal Singh and Sunder Singh.

anchor.surface_text: One Nikka Singh had three sons, Bhagwan Singh, Lal Singh and Sunder Singh. Bhagwan Singh died issueless some years ago and disputes arose between Lal Singh and his brother Sundar Singh

facts.text: Bhagwan Singh died issueless some years ago.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwan Singh died issueless some years ago and disputes arose between Lal Singh and his brother Sundar Singh in regard to the division of the property of Bhagwan Singh.

facts.text: Disputes arose between Lal Singh and Sunder Singh regarding division of Bhagwan Singh's property; Sunder in possession, Lal obtained decrees but Sunder declined to restore possession.

anchor.surface_text: Sunder Singh was in possession of some of his landed properties and Lal Singh obtained a number of decrees against him but Sunder Singh declined to restore possession of the properties to his brother Lal Singh.

facts.text: Relations between Lal Singh and Sunder Singh were considerably strained; not even on speaking terms for some time.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this litigation the relations between Lal Singh and Sunder Singh were considerably strained and it is said that for some time they were not even on speaking terms.

facts.text: Lal Singh married to Mst. Dhan Kaur; two sons: Bagher Singh (murdered) and Arjan Singh (P.W. 5).

anchor.surface_text: Lal Singh is married to Mst. Dhan Kaur and from her he had two sons. One of them Bagher Singh was murdered and the other, Arjan Singh, is P. W. 5.

facts.text: Ajmer Singh is son of Sunder Singh; Banta Singh is his real brother.

anchor.surface_text: Accused Ajmer Singh is the son of Sunder Singh and Banta Singh is his real brother. Ajmer Singh is married to Jagir Kaur and Banta Singh to Kartar Kaur.

facts.text: On evening of 27th January 1948, Jagir Kaur complained to her father-in-law that husband pawned her ear-rings for gambling debts.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged by the prosecution that on the evening of the 27th January, 1948, Jagir Kaur complained to her father-in-law that her husband had pawned her ear-rings in order to pay off his gambling debts.

facts.text: On morning of 28th January 1948, Banta Singh inquired from Ajmer Singh about ear-rings; Ajmer said pawned to Banta Singh Mazhbi.

anchor.surface_text: On the morning of the 28th Banta Singh inquired from Ajmer Singh about this matter and he replied that he had pawned the ear-rings to one Banta Singh Mazhbi.

facts.text: Ajmer Singh, Banta Singh and Teja Singh went to Banta Singh Mazhbi, asked for return of ear-rings; he denied, offered Rs. 30 if oath taken.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after this Ajmer Singh, Banta Singh and one Teja Singh went to Banta Singh Mazhbi and asked him to return the ear- rings but the latter replied that no ornaments had been pawned with him and added that he would give a sum of Rs. 30 to them if Ajmer Singh took an oath

facts.text: Lal Singh present at conversation, supported Mazhbi, leading to exchange of hot words between Lal Singh and party of Sunder Singh's sons and Teja Singh; dispersed without blows.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that Lal Singh was also present when this conversation took place and took up cudgels on behalf of Banta Singh Mazhbi and this led to an exchange of hot words between Lal Singh and the party of Sunder Singhs two sons and their companion Teja Singh. The parties, however, dispersed after exchanging hot words but without coming to blows.

facts.text: At sunset 28th January 1948, Lal Singh and Sunder Singh abused each other from houses opening into common courtyard.

anchor.surface_text: At about sunset the same day Lal Singh and his brother Sunder Singh started abusing each other from their respective houses which open out into a common courtyard.

facts.text: Abuse attracted Arjan Singh, Bagher Singh and Ujagar Singh Mazhbi to Lal Singh's house.

anchor.surface_text: This wordy warfare between the two brothers attracted the attention of Arjan Singh, Bagher Singh and one Ujagar Singh Mazhbi who on hearing the noise came to the house of Lal Singh.

facts.text: Lal Singh challenged Sunder Singh to come out; Sunder Singh, sons Banta and Ajmer, and Teja Singh rushed out armed with spears.

anchor.surface_text: Lal Singh finding himself supported by three others threw out a challenge to Sunder Singh and told him to come out in the open. It is said that Sunder Singh, his two, sons Banta Singh and Ajmer Singh, and Teja Singh, a cousin of theirs, accepted the challenge and rushed out of the house.

facts.text: Teja Singh and Banta Singh armed with spears attacked Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur, inflicted injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Teja Singh and Banta Singh were armed with spears and they made an attack on Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur and inflicted on their persons a number of injuries.

facts.text: Ajmer Singh armed with spear plunged into chest of Bagher Singh who collapsed and died almost instantaneously.

anchor.surface_text: Ajmer Singh, it is said, was armed with a spear and he plunged his weapon into the chest of Bagher Singh who collapsed and died almost instantaneously.

facts.text: Arjan Singh reported incident at police station at 11:45 p.m. after 7 miles travel, stated Ajmer Singh dealt barchha blow to Bagher Singh's chest.

anchor.surface_text: Arjan Singh soon after reported this incident at the police station after travelling a distance of about seven miles at 11-45 p. m. He gave to the police substantially the same version as has now been deposed to by him in the witness box.

facts.text: Police arrested Sunder Singh, Teja Singh and Banta Singh; Ajmer Singh not found initially.

anchor.surface_text: In this report it was stated by Arjan Singh that it was Ajmer Singh who dealt Bagher Singh a barchha blow on his chest and that Bagher Singh fell down at this blow. The police arrested Sunder Singh, Teja Singh and Banta Singh but the appellant could not be found.

facts.text: Ajmer Singh apprehended on 4th December 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Ajmer Singh was apprehended on 4th December, 1948, and as above stated, was tried by the learned Sessions Judge of Ferozepore and acquitted

facts.text: Sunder Singh, Teja Singh, Banta Singh prosecuted under 302/34, convicted under 324 IPC; sentences: Banta and Teja 2 years RI, Sunder 6 months RI; on appeal Sunder acquitted, others reduced.

anchor.surface_text: Sunder Singh, Teja Singh and Banta Singh were prosecuted under section 302/34 but were convicted under section 324, Indian Penal Code, Banta Singh and Teja Singh were sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment each and Sunder Singh to six months rigorous imprisonment. On appeal, Sunder Singh was acquitted and the sentences imposed on Banta Singh and Teja Singh were reduced.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held Ajmer Singh not present at morning quarrel at Banta Singh Mazhbi's shop.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge considered him a wholly independent witness and accepted his evidence about the incident that took place at Banta Singh Mazhbis shop on the morning of the 28th. He held that Ajmer Singh was not present at Banta Singh Mazhbis shop

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on 10 December 1952.

anchor.surface_text: S. Safeer for the appellant. Gopal Singh for the respondent. 1952. December 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MAHAJAN J.

facts.text: High Court reviewed evidence and found variations minor, natural after 27 months; upheld conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The High -Court on appeal minutely reviewed the evidence of these three eye-witnesses and considered that the variations in the statements of witnesses made at- the two trials and which had weighed on- the mind of the Sessions Judge were of a minor and trifling character and were quite natural as the Statements at this trial had been made 27 months after the occurrence

This is an appeal by special leave against that decision. One Nikka Singh had three sons, Bhagwan Singh, Lal Singh and Sunder Singh. Bhagwan Singh died issueless some years ago and disputes arose between Lal Singh and his brother Sundar Singh

Sunder Singh, Teja Singh and Banta Singh were prosecuted under section 302/34 but were convicted under section 324, Indian Penal Code, Banta Singh and Teja Singh were sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment each and Sunder Singh to six months rigorous imprisonment.

Sunder Singh, Teja Singh and Banta Singh were prosecuted under section 302/34 but were convicted under section 324, Indian Penal Code, Banta Singh and Teja Singh were sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment each and Sunder Singh to six months rigorous imprisonment.

the order of acquittal was set aside by the High Court and the appellant was convicted under section 304, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced to ten years rigorous imprisonment. This is an appeal by special leave against that decision.

anchor.surface_text: the examination of the appellant was number in accordance with the provisions of section 342, Criminal Procedure Code.

concepts.interpretation: Requires the court to question the accused separately about each material circumstance which is intended to be used against him to afford a fair and proper opportunity of explaining circumstances which appear against him. The questions must be fair and couched in a form which an ignorant or illiterate person will be able to appreciate and understand. However, every error or omission in compliance does not necessarily vitiate the trial if no prejudice is occasioned to the accused.

issues.text: Whether there were compelling reasons to set aside the order of acquittal and whether due weight was given to the trial judge's opinion on credibility of witnesses

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by Mr. Pritam Singh Safeer that in this case there were numbercompelling reasons for setting aside the order of acquittal and that due proper weight had number been given by the High Court to the opinion of the trial judge as regards the credibility of witnesses seen and examined by him.

anchor.surface_text: In -an appeal under section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the High Court had full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and we are satisfied that it did number in any way exercise it wrongly

arguments.claim: High Court erred: accused not required to explain prima facie case; cannot deny presumption of innocence post-acquittal

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel submitted that the High Court was in error in the view that when a strong prima facie case is made out against an accused person it is his duty to explain the circumstances appearing in evidence against him and he cannot take shelter behind the presumption of innocence and cannot state that the law entitles him to keep his lips sealed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Criticism well founded; presumption reinforced by acquittal; reversal only for very substantial and compelling reasons

arguments.claim: Presumption of innocence reinforced by acquittal; trial court's decision reversible only for very substantial and compelling reasons, not mere failure to explain

anchor.surface_text: We think this criticism is well founded. After an order of acquittal has been made the presumption of inno- cence is further reinforced by that order, and that being so, the trial companyrts decision can be reversed number on the ground that the accused had failed to explain the circumstances appearing against him but only for ,very substantial and companypelling reasons.

arguments.claim: Arjan Singh's testimony reliable: no material discrepancies; selected Ajmer truthfully; no identity mistake possible

anchor.surface_text: As the companyrts below expressed divergent opinions on the credibility of the prosecution witnesses, we had to read the evidence adduced in the case with great care and after doing so, we are on the whole inclined to agree with the view expressed by the High Court. It is difficult to believe that without there being any truth in the fact that the appellant struck Bagher Singh with a barchha, Arjan Singh selected the appellant and ascribed to him that part soon after the occurrence.

arguments.claim: Sessions Judge's reasons for rejecting Arjan Singh not convincing; minor discrepancies exaggerated; hypercritical view

anchor.surface_text: There are numbermaterial discrepancies in the statements made by Arjan Singh on different occasions and in our view the reasons given by the learned Sessions Judge for rejecting his testimony are number companyvincing. We agree with the High Court that there are numbersufficient reasons for distrusting his evidence.

arguments.claim: No mistake in identity: few participants (7-8), few blows

anchor.surface_text: The number of persons who took part in the quarrel was number more than seven or eight and the blows inflicted were few, and in these circumstances Arjan Singh companyld have made numbermistake as to the identity of the person who struck Bagher Singh fatally.

arguments.claim: Fatal blow part corroborated by Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur; no cross-examination on it

anchor.surface_text: This part of -his statement is companyroborated by the evidence of Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur. No cross-examination was directed, against this part of their statements.

arguments.claim: Bishandas' cryptic statement insufficient to reject prosecution; Sessions erred relying on it for absence

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the learned Sessions Judge took too exaggerated a view of the minor discrepancies in these statements and read them with a rather hypercritical mind. Bishandas, whose statement companysiderably impressed him, was only tendered for cross-examination and never made a full statement about the happenings of the 28th morning.

arguments.claim: Ujagar Singh tendered but defence asked no questions about occurrence; no withholding of independent witnesses

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge was number right in rejecting the whole of the prosecution evidence as unreliable merely on the basis of this cryptic statement. Ujagar Singh, the other so-called independent witness, was tendered for cross-examination but the defence did number ask him a single question about the happenings of the 28th.

arguments.claim: Defence led no evidence of alternative version or Ajmer's absence

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the defence also led numberevidence to prove that the fight took place in a manner different from the one described by the prosecution witnesses, or that Ajmer Singh was number present on the occasion.

arguments.claim: High Court had full power under s.417 CrPC to review acquittal evidence; exercised properly

anchor.surface_text: In -an appeal under section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the High Court had full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and we are satisfied that it did number in any way exercise it wrongly

arguments.claim: Injuries on Kartar Kaur and Ujagar Singh irrelevant; prosecution no duty to explain

anchor.surface_text: The injuries on the person of Kartar Kaur and under Singh were number proved to have been inflicted at the time of the occurrence and were of numberconsequence. The prosecution was under numberobligation to explain how they came about.

arguments.claim: Sessions trial vitiated by non-compliance with s.342 CrPC examination

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the trial held by the Sessions Judge was vitiated as the examination of the appellant was number in accordance with the provisions of section 342, Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.court_reasoning: Defective but no prejudice occasioned; simple facts, accused aware via committal and cross-exam; cites Tara Singh v State

arguments.claim: s.342 CrPC requires separate questions on each material circumstance; not discharged by reading committal statement

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that when the Sessions Judge is required by that section to make the examination of the .accused, his duty is number discharged by merely reading over the questions and answers to the accused put in the companymitting magistrates companyrt and by asking him whether he has to say anything about them.

arguments.claim: Every s.342 non-compliance does not vitiate trial if no prejudice

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that every error or omission number in companypliance with the provisions of section 342 does number necessarily vitiate a trial.

holdings.text: After an order of acquittal has been made the presumption of innocence is further reinforced by that order, and that being so, the trial court's decision can be reversed not on the ground that the accused had failed to explain the circumstances appearing against him but only for very substantial and compelling reasons.

anchor.surface_text: We think this criticism is well founded. After an order of acquittal has been made the presumption of inno- cence is further reinforced by that order, and that being so, the trial companyrts decision can be reversed number on the ground that the accused had failed to explain the circumstances appearing against him but only for ,very substantial and companypelling reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in requiring explanation from accused on prima facie case post-acquittal; presumption strengthened, reversal needs substantial reasons.

holdings.text: In an appeal under section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the High Court had full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and we are satisfied that it did not in any way exercise it wrongly.

anchor.surface_text: In -an appeal under section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the High Court had full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and we are satisfied that it did number in any way exercise it wrongly

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court reviewed evidence minutely and correctly assessed minor variations as natural.

holdings.text: When the Sessions Judge is required by section 342 CrPC to examine the accused, his duty is not discharged by merely reading over the questions and answers from the committing court and asking if he has anything to say about them; the accused must be questioned separately about each material circumstance intended to be used against him.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that when the Sessions Judge is required by that section to make the examination of the .accused, his duty is number discharged by merely reading over the questions and answers to the accused put in the companymitting magistrates companyrt and by asking him whether he has to say anything about them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Tara Singh v State; object is to give fair opportunity to explain; questions must be fair and comprehensible to illiterate.

holdings.text: Every error or omission in compliance with section 342 CrPC does not necessarily vitiate the trial if no prejudice is occasioned to the accused.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that every error or omission number in companypliance with the provisions of section 342 does number necessarily vitiate a trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defective examination here caused no prejudice; simple facts, accused aware via committal, cross-exam, denied guilt due to enmity.

holdings.text: The prosecution evidence is reliable; there were no material discrepancies warranting rejection; Ajmer Singh inflicted the fatal spear blow on Bagher Singh's chest.

anchor.surface_text: As the companyrts below expressed divergent opinions on the credibility of the prosecution witnesses, we had to read the evidence adduced in the case with great care and after doing so, we are on the whole inclined to agree with the view expressed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Own review of evidence; minor variations natural after 27 months; Arjan Singh consistent with FIR; no identity mistake; corroborated; defence no alternative evidence; Sessions Judge hypercritical.

holdings.text: The prosecution was under no obligation to explain injuries on Kartar Kaur and Ujagar Singh as they were not proved to have been inflicted at the time of occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The injuries on the person of Kartar Kaur and under Singh were number proved to have been inflicted at the time of the occurrence and were of numberconsequence. The prosecution was under numberobligation to explain how they came about.
